title: PNG moves to arrest former PM Peter O'Neill on corruption charges
text:
Mr O'Neill has denied the allegations and said the warrant was "false and fabricated".

He was toppled by his former ally James Marape in late May and the new prime minister came to power vowing to ‘‘take back PNG’’.

"Now is the time to tackle the cancer of corruption that has taken hold, using the power of prosecution and all other means that we have at our disposal," Mr Marape told the Lowy Institute during a visit to Sydney in July.

Mr Kramer went further in an interview with The Australian Financial Review, vowing to investigate Mr O'Neill, who he described as the "centre point" of patronage networks in PNG.

He promised to deliver some "real hits" before the end of 2019.

Mr Kramer, who has been an outspoken critic of Mr O'Neill, pledged to run his own investigation into the so-called UBS loan affair, under which PNG borrowed $1.2 billion from the investment bank in March 2014 to buy a 10 per cent stake in the ASX-listed Oil Search.

PNG is estimated to have lost about $420 million on the deal after Oil Search shares fell sharply following a drop in oil prices.

"The whole deal from day one was bad … you don’t borrow [money] to invest in the stock market,” Mr Kramer said.

Advertisement

The Marape government has established a royal commission into the UBS loan and will investigate how the investment bank came to complete the deal and if any laws were broken in the process. The terms of reference are suitably broad to allow related transactions to be scrutinised.

Retired Australian Federal Court judge John Gilmour, QC, will sit as a "second commissioner" alongside chairman Sir Salamo Injia on the inquiry.

Perth barrister Matthew Howard, SC, has been appointed counsel assisting the royal commission, while his junior counsel is fellow West Australian Alexander Mossop.

Mr Kramer also said he would investigate any links between controversial Manus Island refugee contractor Paladin and Mr O'Neill.

Mr Kramer said one avenue of investigation was any ownership links between Mr O'Neill and security firm Black Swan, which was purchased by Paladin for an undisclosed sum in July last year.

“That is what I want to establish, to see if there is any clear lead between Black Swan and Peter O’Neill," Mr Kramer said.
description: An arrest warrant has been issue for Peter O'Neill who was dogged by allegations of corruption during his nearly eight years in power.
